THE RISK OF MONEY LAUNDERING

Page

Table of Contents

Stealing money from bank accounts

 

In 2011, a former Westpac employee was charged over an alleged plan to steal up to $100 million from customers of major Australian banks.

 

Police alleged that the 36-year old man was one of several people who were part of a $1.1 million theft that involved funnelling stolen money into bank accounts set up using stolen identities of individuals who no longer lived in Australia.

 

The man was charged with money laundering, participating in a criminal group, dishonestly obtaining a financial advantage, and dealing with identity information with intent. An investigating officer said, "They've had people inside the banks … that have been acting corruptly in their role and that has certainly assisted these people in this conspiracy."

 

Employees within an organisation could pose a significant risk of money laundering and terrorism financing to the organisation itself. There have been several reported cases of insider complicity where employees of a financial institution use their position to avoid screening processes for money laundering.

 

Employees assigned to high-risk areas of your organisation, high-risk customers such as the ones discussed earlier, and designated services accounts should be subject to particular scrutiny. You should also look out for relatives of employees and those employees acting with power of attorney.
